column1: Calcifications are tiny deposits of calcium in your breast tissue.
The calcium you eat or take in as medicine does not cause calcifications in the breast.

Causes may include: - Calcium deposits in the arteries inside your breasts - History of breast infection - Noncancerous (benign) breast lumps or cysts - Past injury to the breast tissue - Powders, deodorants, or ointments that are placed on the skin Large, rounded calcifications (macrocalcifications) are common in women over age 50.
